subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
author: April Abercrombie
full_text:
------=_NextPart_000_0025_01C9D185.EDC499F0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

So if the number of bytes match then they are the same bytes? See where my =
confusion comes in?

How does one do a bit-level comparison? Is there a pro=
gram that does that, or is there some way of comparison by looking at the f=
ile's properties?

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Rj 
  To: EVP-IT=
C@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 3:35 PM
  Subject: Re: [EVP=
-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON





        A file's content, it'=
s integrity, is simply the bytes (and their bits) in the file.  If the file=
's content integrity is changed, that is, by definition, changing the bytes=
.  If the bytes in there are not changed, then that integrity has not chang=
ed.

        It is possible to mess with other things about a file (like it=
s name, its suffix, or its ownership) but this does not effect the contents=
, and so would not affect that integrity, or the sound of the file (assumin=
g you could read it at all after changing the ownership, or the suffix, etc=
).

        When you do your tests, if you cannot do a bit level comparison=
, I would recommend at least checking the file sizes.  If they are identica=
l, there is a very high probability that the content has not changed.




 =
       --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombieghostresear=
ch.com> wrote:


          From: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombieghostr=
esearch.com>
          Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTIO=
N JON
          To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
          Date: Sunday, May 10,=
 2009, 2:28 PM



          Admittedly I do not know much about bit-level c=
omparisons, what they can or can't show so I will have to leave that to you=
. I have doubts because I worry once a file's integrity has been messed wit=
h, I wonder that even though the bits match, maybe that doesn't mean they a=
re the same quality as the original. I really don't know though what is pos=
sible or impossible when it comes to this area.

          "It is probably =
possible to set up an email compression scheme that does do lossy audio com=
pression.  My tests show my setup does not.  If you'd like me to help test =
your setup, we can do that too. From what I see, lossy compression from an =
attachment would be very unusual."

          The problem I have is that no=
t just from Jon, but I have heard it from other people, and a professional =
and they all said that loss is possible. From all that, my conclusion was t=
hat maybe in some cases loss was possible.

          However, your argumen=
ts do put doubt back into my mind, which pisses me off, because I had origi=
nally argued feverishly for no loss, then I heard different from different =
sources and decided to do what I thought was the right thing by contacting =
a third party professional. So after all that, I decided I was licked and h=
ad to eat crow.

          Now I am back at square one, from the other side=
 LOL!!! Computer people have been wrong in the past.


          "It is pro=
bably possible to set up an email compression scheme that does do lossy aud=
io compression.  My tests show my setup does not.  If you'd like me to help=
 test your setup, we can do that too. From what I see, lossy compression fr=
om an attachment would be very unusual."

          I have not tested it fr=
om my computer, as I haven't had any problems with loss. I would really lik=
e to have Jon work with us on this, because he was the original person who =
told me I was wrong.

          But I will test it from my side. I will sen=
d a wav file to one of my other addresses. Then I will download and compare=
. If I think I hear a difference, then maybe I can have you do a bit-level =
comparison on the files.

          Either way, I am going to get to the bo=
ttom of this.



            ----- Original Message ----- 
            From=
: Rj 
            To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
            Sent: Sunday, M=
ay 10, 2009 2:59 PM
            Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules=
-ATTENTION JON


                  Yes you can tell loss of quality by a bi=
t-level comparison.  An audio file is just a file of bytes, that is later i=
nterpreted by an audio player.  Two files with the exact same contents, whe=
ther they are audio or image or a dababase or an exe, are indistinguishable=
 from each other.  That is, if I copied the contents of one to a new file, =
and the contents of the other to a new file, and asked you which file each =
came from, there would be no way to tell.  Even the audio player could not =
tell.  The data is identical, and so the sound (or the picture, etc) would =
be identical.

                  Yes I did listen to the results, but that =
is not the best test (they sounded identical, but that is a subjective opin=
ion).  The real test is compring the contents.  Identical contents means in=
dentical data, means identical audio.

                  It is probably pos=
sible to set up an email compression scheme that does do lossy audio compre=
ssion.  My tests show my setup does not.  If you'd like me to help test you=
r setup, we can do that too. From what I see, lossy compression from an att=
achment would be very unusual.


                  --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Apr=
il Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


            =
        From: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
    =
                Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
 =
                   To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                    Date: S=
unday, May 10, 2009, 1:50 PM



                    I have not personally e=
xperienced the loss myself. Jon from this list is the one who originally to=
ld me about it. I have also heard of it happening to a few other people. Af=
ter my conversation with Jon, I talked to a computer professional, and he t=
old me that you can experience loss in attached files.

                   =
 I don't know if you would be able to tell loss of quality in an audio file=
 with a bit-level comparison. Just because the data has been replaced, does=
n't have to mean it is perfect.

                    Did you listen to the =
before and after results?

                    Jon-Please relay your experi=
ence with the loss of quality on emailed files.


                      ---=
-- Original Message ----- 
                      From: Rj 
                =
      To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
                      Sent: Sunday, May=
 10, 2009 2:38 PM
                      Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploadi=
ng rules


                            I can't vouch for your computer or s=
ervers, but I just did some tests, and sent a 2.1MB wav file from MSN to Ya=
hoo and back, once allowing compression, and once turning it off.   I was a=
ble to verify that one was compressed and one was not, by checking the size=
s when they arrived at Yahoo. Once they came back to MSN, I then did a bit-=
level comparison of the original, and the ones sent around email.  They wer=
e all identical, which indicates lossless compression.

                   =
         If you have a file you'd like me to test for you, let me know.  Bu=
t I wouldn't take someone's word for how your server's work, without testin=
g them yourself.



                            --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April =
Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


               =
               From: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. co=
m>
                              Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rule=
s
                              To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
              =
                Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 12:50 PM



                   =
           For executables, you may be right. However, for wav files, the c=
ompression during email is not loss less. 

                              I=
 used to think as you do, in that the emailed attachment of a wav file woul=
d not loose anything. After a lengthy discourse with another member here, I=
 learned that I was wrong. The reason why I did not realize it in the first=
 place is that when I would email a wav file, I would intentionally keep it=
 in very small segments, to keep file size down. This was just for ease of =
transfer. But because of this, I had not experienced any noticeable loss.

=
                              Now it may be in some cases, depending on the=
 servers or what have you that the file goes through, that the loss may be =
less or more. But once the attachment is downloaded, the quality has been f=
ound to be less then the original wav.

                              Again=
 though you can only really tell when the wav file is large.

             =
                 ----- Original Message ----- 
                            =
    From: Rj 
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com =

                                Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 1:36 PM
       =
                         Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules


    =
                            The kind of compression that occurs during an e=
mail attachment is "lossless": it compress the file cleverly without losing=
 information.  For example, if I had a program in some .exe files, and I se=
nt it over email, it could compress it.  But if it lost even one bit, the r=
esulting exe file would not execute again after it was uncompressed on the =
other side.

                                This kind of compression does =
things like looking for common patterns in the file, and replacing them wit=
h a token.  A rough example would be if it found "Howdy Neighbor" in a file=
 20 times, it could replace all the occurances with say $HN1.  And also wri=
te a little dictionary in there someplace that says "$HN1=3DHowdy Neighbor"=
.

                                When the file gets to its destination it=
 can be uncompressed, and all occurences of $HN1 are replaced with "Howdy N=
eighbor".  So it was compressed (instead of 14 characters each, it only nee=
ded 4, plus the dictionary), but lost no data.

                           =
     Some formats, like jpeg and mp3. are not lossless.  Depending on the l=
evel of compression, some level of data is lost, and so cannot be recovered=
 or reconstructed later.

                                Rick



         =
                       --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercr=
ombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


                                From: Ap=
ril Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>

ate: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 10:26 AM



                                Anot=
her thing:

                                I recently found this out. When=
 you email a file, if it is not saved as a compressed format, the email fil=
tering process will actually compress the file automatically.

            =
                    So even if you have attached a wav. file, it will loose=
 resolution over the email process. It will not sound exactly the same as t=
he original wav. file. How much it differs depends on the size of the file =
you are attaching. If it is a very large file, it will sound much different=
.

                                The only exception to this is if the wav=
. file is small enough that the filtering process will ignore it. It has to=
 be pretty small though, like under 1 MB (I am not exactly sure of the thre=
shold).

                                The best way to share files over t=
he internet if you want them as close to the original as possible is to upl=
oad them directly to a website.

                                ----- Orig=
inal Message ----- 
                                From: Rj 
             =
                   To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
                          =
      Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 10:54 AM
                                S=
ubject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules



                             =
   Pixelization doesn't clean-up the data: it replaces it.  Imagine taking =
a picture of a field of flowers, and beginning to add levels or pixelizatio=
n to the picture.  Soon, you would not be able to tell there were flowers t=
here at all.  You would see a lot of colored blocks.

                     =
           Or in the other direction, imagine you are looking at a competel=
y randomize bunch of pixes on your screen: a complete screen of truely rand=
om static snow.  Pixelizing this, after a while, you would again start to s=
ee colored blocks.

                                What's happening is tha=
t it is processing an area of the image, taking (for instance) the average =
value of that entire area, and replacing all the blocks in that area with t=
he average.  In video processing, this would result in a field of multi-col=
ored flowers being replaced by, for instance, a big greyish-bluish block, w=
ith no resemblance to flowers.  In the noise example, it maybe replace all =
the random pixels with another big greyish-bluish block.  If you did not kn=
ow beforehand what the original picture was, you couldn't tell whether your=
 pixelized image was really a field of flowers, a chevy, the sky with cloud=
s, or a random bunch of pixels.

                                It works t=
he same with the sound files.  Taking something as complex as speech, and r=
eplacing frequencies with their averages, loses the speech the farther you =
go, until you head strange fluctuating square waves.  Doing the same to ran=
dom static will eventually produce the same thing.  And random fluctuating =
square waves can sound a bit like speech - or at least, you could have fun =
sharing with each other what you thing they 'sound like'.





            =
                    --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com=
> wrote:


                                From: Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ y=
ahoo.com>
                                Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploa=
ding rules
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
   =

        =
                        I always save the whole file in wav format then do =
my clips as mp3. Then I have the original for analysis. 

                 =
               As far as pixelization of non sounds/white noise whos to say=
 that isnt being manipulated by them as well LOL. Water is a form of white =
noise. I seem to remember some experiments done with blank tapes/film, no r=
ecording done yet there were voices/images there. I find it all interesting=
.

                                Just a thought. Ok off to work now!
    =
                            Misty

                                --- On S=
un, 5/10/09, Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com> wrote:


                            =
    From: Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com>
                                Subject:=
 Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                                To: EVP=
-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                                Date: Sunday, May 10,=
 2009, 11:47 AM


                                Be a bit careful of forma=
ts like mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the sounds though.   Wh=
ile some formats (like wav) can store the audio very close to the way it wa=
s recorded, formats like mp3 compress the file, and in so doing lose some o=
f the sonic details.  This may not be a big deal in music, where the audio =
is fairly clear to begin with.  But with sound sources with a lot of noise =
(like evps), this can not only obscure any real sounds, but pixelize non-so=
unds (like white noise) and make them start to sound like speech.

        =
                        So mp3 might be good for sharing the data, once you=
've already formed an opinion based on an analysis of the wav file.  But mp=
3 is not good as a medium for analysis.  It can lead to many false positive=
s and misinterpretations.

                                --- On Sun, 5/10=
/09, Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com> wrote:


                         =
       From: Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com>

unday, May 10, 2009, 8:26 AM

=

ight thats how you save it. For most softwares its under save as or export =
as. If you still have trouble use one of the links I posted to help ya out.=


                                Misty

                <TD vAlign=3Dtop>Yes you can tell loss of quality by a bit=
-level 
                  comparison.  An audio file is just a file of=
 bytes, that 
                  is later interpreted by an audio player.&nb=
sp; Two files with 
                  the exact same contents, whether they=
 are audio or image or a 
                  dababase or an exe, are indisti=
nguishable from each 
                  other.  That is, if I copied t=
he contents of one to a new 
                  file, and the contents of th=
e other to a new file, and asked 
                  you which file each cam=
e from, there would be no way to 
                  tell.  Even the au=
dio player could not tell.  The 
                  data is identical, =
and so the sound (or the picture, etc) 
                  would be identica=
l.<BR><BR>Yes I did listen to the results, 
                  but that is n=
ot the best test (they sounded identical, but 
                  that is a =
subjective opinion).  The real test is compring 
                  the=
 contents.  Identical contents means indentical data, 
               =
   means identical audio.<BR><BR>It is probably possible to set 
          =
        up an email compression scheme that does do lossy audio 
          =
        compression.  My tests show my setup does not.  If 
     =
             you'd like me to help test your setup, we can do that too. 
  =
                From what I see, lossy compression from an attachment would=
 be 
                  very unusual.<BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 5/10/09, Apr=
il 
                  Abercrombie <I><april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. 
=
                  com></I></B> wrote:<BR>
                  <BLOCKQUOTE =

lly told me about it. I have also heard of 
                    it hap=
pening to a few other people. After my 
                    conve=
rsation with Jon, I talked to a computer 
                    professi=
onal, and he told me that you can experience loss in 
                    a=
ttached files.</FONT></DIV>

l comparison. Just because the data has been 
                    replaced,=

                          <TD vAlign=3Dtop>I can't vouc=
h for your computer or 
                            servers, but I just did=
 some tests, and sent a 2.1MB 
                            wav file from MS=
N to Yahoo and back, once allowing 
                            compression=
, and once turning it off.   I 
                            was a=
ble to verify that one was compressed and one 
                            =
was not, by checking the sizes when they arrived at 
                      =
      Yahoo. Once they came back to MSN, I then did a 
                    =
        bit-level comparison of the original, and the ones 
               =
             sent around email.  They were all identical, 
           =
                 which indicates lossless compression.<BR><BR>If you 
     =
                       have a file you'd like me to test for you, let me 
 =
                           know.  But I wouldn't take someone's word f=
or 
                            how your server's work, without testing the=
m 
                            yourself.<BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 5/10=
/09, 
                            April Abercrombie <I><april@abercrombi=
egh 
                            ostresearch. com></I></B> wrote:<BR>

chment of a wav file would not loose

ything. After a lengthy discourse with another

                    =

                         found to be less then the original

size=3D2

he wav file is

                                <TD vAlign=3Dtop>Th=
e kind of compression that 
                                occurs during a=
n email attachment is "lossless": 
                                it compr=
ess the file cleverly without losing 
                                infor=
mation.  For example, if I had a 
                                prog=
ram in some .exe files, and I sent it over 
                               =
 email, it could compress it.  But if it 
                            =
    lost even one bit, the resulting exe file would 
                      =
          not execute again after it was uncompressed on 
                 =
               the other side.<BR><BR>This kind of compression 
           =
                     does things like looking for common patterns in 
     =
                           the file, and replacing them with a token. =
 
                                A rough example would be if it found "How=
dy 
                                Neighbor" in a file 20 times, it could =
replace 
                                all the occurances with say $HN1.&=
nbsp; And also 
                                write a little dictionary i=
n there someplace 
                                that says "$HN1=3DHowdy =
Neighbor".<BR><BR>When the 
                                file gets to it=
s destination it can be 
                                uncompressed, and =
all occurences of $HN1 are 
                                replaced with "=
Howdy Neighbor".  So it was 
                                compresse=
d (instead of 14 characters each, it 
                                only =
needed 4, plus the dictionary), but lost no 
                              =
  data.<BR><BR>Some formats, like jpeg and mp3. 
                          =
      are not lossless.  Depending on the level 
                     =
           of compression, some level of data is lost, and 
               =
                 so cannot be recovered or reconstructed 
                 =
               later.<BR><BR>Rick<BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 
          =
                      5/10/09, April Abercrombie 
                         =
       <I><april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. 
                           =
     com></I></B> wrote:<BR>

ubject: Re: [EVP-ITC]

e=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro">I recently 
                                found=
 this out. When you email a file, if it is 
                               =
 not saved as a compressed format, the email 
                             =
   filtering process will actually compress the 
                          =
      file automatically.</FONT></DIV>

><FONT size=3D2

yriad Pro">So even if

wav. file, it will loose 
                                resolution over t=
he email process. It will not 
                                sound exactl=
y the same as the original wav. 
                                file. How =
much it differs depends on the size of 
                                the=
 file you are attaching. If it is a 
                                very&n=
bsp;large file, it will sound much 
                                differe=
nt.</FONT></DIV>
                                <DIV><FONT size=3D2 
     =
                           face=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT> </DIV>
        =
                        <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro">The only 
 =
                               exception to this is if the wav. file is sma=
ll 
                                enough that the filtering process will =
ignore 
                                it. It has to be pretty small thoug=
h, like under 
                                1 MB (I am not exactly =
sure of the 
                                threshold).</FONT></DIV>

                               =
 <TD vAlign=3Dtop><BR>Pixelization doesn't clean-up 
                      =
          the data: it replaces it.  Imagine taking a 
               =
                 picture of a field of flowers, and beginning to 
         =
                       add levels or pixelization to the picture.  
  =
                              Soon, you would not be able to tell there wer=
e 
                                flowers there at all.  You would se=
e a lot 
                                of colored blocks.<BR><BR>Or in th=
e other 
                                direction, imagine you are looking=
 at a 
                                competely randomize bunch of pixes o=
n your 
                                screen: a complete screen of truely=
 random 
                                static snow.  Pixelizing this=
, after a 
                                while, you would again start to =
see colored 
                                blocks.<BR><BR>What's happenin=
g is that it is 
                                processing an area of the =
image, taking (for 
                                instance) the average v=
alue of that entire area, 
                                and replacing al=
l the blocks in that area with 
                                the average=
.  In video processing, this 
                                would re=
sult in a field of multi-colored flowers 
                                b=
eing replaced by, for instance, a big 
                                grey=
ish-bluish block, with no resemblance to 
                                f=
lowers.  In the noise example, it maybe 
                             =
   replace all the random pixels with another big 
                        =
        greyish-bluish block.  If you did not know 
                  =
              beforehand what the original picture was, you 
              =
                  couldn't tell whether your pixelized image was 
         =
                       really a field of flowers, a chevy, the sky with 
  =
                              clouds, or a random bunch of pixels.<BR><BR>I=
t 
                                works the same with the sound files.&nbs=
p; 
                                Taking something as complex as speech, =
and 
                                replacing frequencies with their avera=
ges, loses 
                                the speech the farther you go, =
until you head 
                                strange fluctuating square =
waves.  Doing 
                                the same to random stat=
ic will eventually 
                                produce the same thing.=
  And random 
                                fluctuating square waves=
 can sound a bit like 
                                speech - or at least=
, you could have fun sharing 
                                with each oth=
er what you thing they 'sound 
                                like'.<BR><B=
R><BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 
                                5/10/09, =
Misty Dawn <I><bulletbabea@ 
                                yahoo.com&g=
t;</I></B> wrote:<BR>

                                vAlign=3Dtop>
     =
                           <DIV>I always save the whole file in wav format =

                                then do my clips as mp3. Then I have the 
=
                                original for analysis. </DIV>
             =
                   <DIV> </DIV>
                                <DIV>A=
s far as pixelization of non sounds/white 
                                =
noise whos to say that isnt being manipulated by 
                         =
       them as well LOL. Water is a form of white 
                        =
        noise. I seem to remember some experiments done 
                  =
              with blank tapes/film, no recording done 
              =
                  yet there were voices/images there. I find it 
          =
                      all interesting.</DIV>

   <TABLE border=3D0 cellSpacing=3D0 cellPadding=3D0>
                     =
           <TBODY>
                                <TR>
                   =
             <TD vAlign=3Dtop>Be a bit careful of formats like 
           =
                     mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the 
     =
                           sounds though.   While some formats 
 =
                               (like wav) can store the audio very close to=
 the 
                                way it was recorded, formats like mp3=
 compress 
                                the file, and in so doing lose s=
ome of the sonic 
                                details.  This may n=
ot be a big deal in 
                                music, where the audio=
 is fairly clear to begin 
                                with.  But =
with sound sources with a lot of 
                                noise (li=
ke evps), this can not only obscure any 
                                re=
al sounds, but pixelize non-sounds (like white 
                           =
     noise) and make them start to sound like 
                            =
    speech.<BR><BR>So mp3 might be good for sharing 
                      =
          the data, once you've already formed an opinion 
                =
                based on an analysis of the wav file.  But 
          =
                      mp3 is not good as a medium for analysis.  
    =
                            It can lead to many false positives and 
      =
                          misinterpretations.<BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 
      =

        =
